CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, November 2, 1946, pg. 4, reads: "Tale of Two Cafes - Alleged rackteer [racketeer] Frank Valenti's $45,000 Spaghetti Village failed to serve her because of her color, Mrs. Marie Mosby, 2605 Webster Avenue, charged in a suit borught [brought] before Alderman Harry Fitzgerald this week. Mrs. Mosby accused two waitresses at the establishment of discrimination.  The Pig & Chick Barbecue, next door to Spaghetti Village, just as lavish and similarly decorated with the same type front and neon signs, has an attractive Negro woman cooking their chickens and barbecue in their window.  An Italian chef cooks spaghetti as a similar ad in Spaghetti Village window.  Pig & Chick Barbecue boasts that a Negro woman's hands sweeten the taste of their meats while Sphaghetti [sic] Village waitresses have been accused of failing to allow a Negro woman to eat their food. - Harris Photo."
TitMainTitle: Two women looking into window of Pig and Chick Bar-B-Q restaurant, with Spaghetti Village at 5811 next door, Frankstown Avenue, East Liberty
